This place has such a cool vibe. Amazing and massive beer selection!!! Amazing!! One of the best and high quality I've ever seen. Their food menu is versatile and unique! Highly recommend, I'm not a vegetarian but their mushroom sandwich sounded so different. And holy cow! Shit was amazeballs! It was super hearty and filling and damn delicious and dare I say healthy, and I wasn't even going for healthy. If you are in the area you will not be disappointed!

Pleasantly surprised.  
The whole family went to try Brasserie V on Friday night.  There was a 20 minute wait, but there was enough room for the kids to sit down and for the parents to have a beer.
Once seated, our waitress was very attentive and friendly.  They have kids meals for $4.95. Well done Brasserie V!  Parents still get to order a special meal and their kids are happy as well.  We ordered V Burgers and a giant bowl of mussels.  Kids meal choices were simple but all good stuff; grilled cheese, spaghetti, etc. with sides.  Even came with a toy too!
V Burgers were just as yummy as the menu exclaimed them to be.  The onions put it over the top for me.  They really hit the mark.  Burger cooked perfectly.  The artichoke side salad was a little bland but we poured some of the mussel broth over it.  Now we're talking.
The mussels were perfect.  My 8 year old mussel connoisseur said they were the best he's had.  There were plenty of the little bivalves in there to keep a person busy for a while.  
The waitress kept the drinks coming, talked to our kids and helped make this first visit a great one.  Everyone wants to come back.  Bravo!

While in town, this was another must that my cousin raved about. So I was pretty excited to try it. From what I had heard, Brasserie V had an outstanding list of beers, and amazing food.

We walked in and it had an old victorian, dark & cool kinda feel to it. We got seated right away, in the back right by the kitchen. Our waiter was fantastic, and patient with us as we took a little bit on what we wanted to drink since there were pages upon pages of all different beer from around the world to choose from. 

I honestly can not remember what beer I had gotten unfortunately, all I know is that it was an IPA since it was National IPA Day! For my dinner I ended up getting an Apple Swiss, with mixed greens as a side, we also got the truffle frites which was great, my only complaint with the Apple Swiss sandwich was that the baguette was extremely hard, I thought my teeth were going to rip out from trying to bite down on it so hard. 

Truly other than the hard baguette, my experience here was great! I can't wait to go again!

The food is great here and the beer/wine list is expansive. But I noticed a lot of very young children and babies coming through the door. I thought, they must have a tremendous kids menu to warranty so much attention from families. Sure enough, one of the previous reviewers mentioned the kids menu and even a toy they get. What is this, McDonald's? If you love the babble of childish noises with your Belgium beer, step right up. Best of all, the babies crying really carry through the place, due to all the hard surface.

Like many other reviewers it seems, I left Brasserie V really impressed. First off, my son and i had really good food--a V burger and mussels and fries that were outstanding. Secondly, a really tasty belgian beer that I don't remember the name of-I'm more of a wine guy than a beer guy but this beer was outstanding. The Bartender/Server (we ate at the bar) was generous enough to pour me 4 small glasses of 4 different beers so that i could pick one i liked--again--I'm not a beer expert. But, I found the beer i liked and it was absolutely delicious. Best of all though, our server was a true gentleman. He gave my son great insight on UW (we were in Madison to tour the campus). His kindness and attention capped off the dinner. Bottom line--great food-great atmosphere-superb staff!! Can't wait to return.

You guys deserve 6 stars for the beer. Very knowledgeable, and one day I hope to get through 3 pages worth of beer on the list before it changes - doubt that is happening anytime soon. But a great place to stick to favorites, explore diverse tastes and be experimental with beer! Food is also good, so a plus. 
My favorite though, is to sit by the bar with H and explore the beer menu. 
A big shout out to the guys behind the bar - very friendly and helpful, plus you get most shots into the cork container!

We were in the Monroe area Friday evening so decided to stop in at Brasserie V for a beverage. The place was busy but it was early and they were able to seat us. Upon learning it was our first time at Brasserie V, our waitress was excited to give us the run down. Cultivating a European cafe feel, an extensive beer list, and tasty sounding appetizers we decided to order some food as well. We ended up ordering three beers and two starters. The Barbary Barrel Noir and the Dynamo Donut Barrel Noir from Almanac were outstanding. I have not found those elsewhere in the area so it was great to see different offerings. Our waitress highly recommended the frites, so we ordered those as well as the fondue. The fondue was served in a large crock with apple slices and bread pieces and there was easily enough cheese for 4 or 6 people. Even using our frites we ran out of dipping material long before we ran out of cheese. I loved the fondue experience and the volume of cheese was incredible. It was definitely a fun dish to try and we were stuffed afterwards. There were many other amazing sounding dishes on the menu. The only downside was that there was definitely a wait in getting our beers after we ordered them. That being said, I will definitely go back and would highly recommend the Brasserie V to others.

Brasserie V is pretty similar to the other modern, trendy dining locations in Madison.

The atmosphere is hip and lively, the food is wholesome and delicious (I'm looking at you, white truffle fries, pork ribs and duck breast), the wait inevitable and the prices fair.

However, what really makes this place stand out among the rest is their drinks menu. And by menu, I mean a short book. Yes, they basically have pages on pages on pages of the different kinds of brew they serve. I don't care if you're the most picky person on this planet when it comes to beer, but you WILL find something you like.

If you couldn't already tell, I'm a huge fan of their brew selection. Some of my favorites: Rochefort 10, Malheur, Schloss Eggenberg Samichlaus and the Konig Pilsener. And if you don't recognize any of these beers, then this place has definitely done their job correctly. 

Come here for the food, but stay for the draaanks!!

I have been here before for mussels, which is what they are famous for... And here I am, getting it again for the second time.... And I am greatly disappointed.

A third of the mussels aren't "opened" and technically you aren't supposed to eat them. And I nicely told the waiter and wanted him to reflect to the kitchen and he was basically ignoring my opinion and said that it's always been that case....

Poor food, poorer service.

Never coming back.

My finance and I were on Monroe and starving. I heard great things about this place. We walked up and no one was there. We decided to sit at the front window. Great little place we thought. Ordered our food. And waited, as people piled into the restaurant, everyone working was super attentive and kind. Directing people to the few tables that were left, they were efficient and quite lovely. After waiting for what seemed like forever, I had to use the restroom. 

This should have been my first sign. Not only did the bathroom stink to high heaven, but shit was falling off the walls. It was dirty and quite nasty. I felt like I would never escape or be the same after that bathroom. But you really can't judge a place on the bathroom. Right?

We heard the chef bell ring multiple times and each time reared our heads like Pavlovian dogs. Finally, our food came. I ordered an avocado blt. I immediately tore into it, and it was fantastic! Nueske's bacon, perfect amount of everything. Just perfect. Until...yikes what is this...a hair! Eieeeiei!!! 

If there is one thing I cannot handle in my food it is hair. So I slowly pulled it out and showed my finance. He knows me, so he said please do not puke right here. I held it together and put it in my napkin. I knew I would not eat another bite. Then suddenly as he was devouring his food, he sees it, not just one but two hairs. He decided to keep eating, yes it was that good. He ate around them. He left the hairs to show the waitress. When he pulled them out they were so long and cooked entirely with the food, I had to excuse myself because I was gagging so hard. 

Previous to finding not one, but many hairs in our food on both dishes, we were discussing how this could be our new go-to place for yum. After that, well I cannot eat there again.  I would recommend the restaurant investing in some hairnets. Their food is good, but not hair worthy. The waitress was a sweetheart about it, and I appreciate that. I would recommend it only if you don't mind what you may find in your food.

Best food. Best beer. Best service. The owner is kind, the wait staff prompt and polite, the chefs world-class, and the bartenders like old friends. Wouldn't trade this place for the world. Truly my favorite spot in all of Madison and not a thing I would change about it. Wish I could give it 10 stars.

Love the updated menu. I've had 3 of the sandwiches over the past 3 weeks. Every one of them was good. Most recently there with colleagues from out of town. Great service and food. All my friends thought the whole package was great.

The first time I came a few years ago, I got the steak frites. It was hard to chew and too dry. If you're the type who loves to eat meat or steak because it's meat or steak, then it's a good deal for lunch. 

I went there again recently for dinner as a vegetarian and got a sandwich. I got the avocado BLT without bacon. It came with bacon. I didn't complain and just took it out and ate half of the very plain sandwich. It wasn't exciting so I focused more on talking with my friends. My vegetarian friend also got a salad because she couldn't find anything that looked good. Their menu is primarily meat dishes or sandwiches. I wish they had more hearty or creative vegetarian options which seems to be normal on most menus these days. 

Lunch hour was very quiet and empty. 
It's the kind of place that gets a loud buzz when a lot of people are there so I couldn't really hear my friends. I wouldn't suggest taking a date there during the weekend. 

The ambience is that of an upscale pub which is good for Monroe street.

The beer selection is wonderful. The food....   truffle fries were the best I've ever had. The summer v burger was small and not worth $12. I want to mention that the two other people we ate with were happy with what they ordered and didn't share in my bummed attitude. In my personal opinion, this place is great for drinks or starters. If you are HUNGRY.... Don't go here.

I have been going to Bras V once or twice a month for years now and while the wait time is occasionally an annoyance and I have had one or two disappointing meals the beer and frites simply are unmatched in Madison.  

In particular the Belgian taps are the stars of the show, in my opinion if you are not ordering off the first page of the drinks list you are doing it wrong though their wine selection is supposed to be good I can not speak to that.  The price is steep, though as I tell my cheaper friends when you are drinking a super tasty 11% beer you do not need more than one or two.

The food has varied over time with some seasonal hits and misses.  The frites are the best in Madison, best I have had anywhere really and pretty much every french fry I eat is a mild disappointment comparatively.  For lunch the BLT is excellent and the turkey sandwich is sometimes quite good but is more variable.  For dinner the mussels are my current favorite though they seem much less intense than they used to, the broth used to be buttery and rich to the point of almost being too much, the last few times it has been much lighter.  I have also enjoyed the steak, it's not a fancy cut for the price but the sauce and side with it are quite good.  The burgers are quite tasty and refined though not quite as good as the Bad Breath burger at The Weary Traveller.

One thing I have not tried is the cheese/sausage plates.  From what I have seen they are not impressive for the cost and being a native around here I can have the same cheeses at home with money left over to buy an Abt12 next time I am at the Brasserie.

My advice : Stop whatever you're doing and go to Brasserie V, right now. 

This place is my ULTIMATE Madison fav, my never-fail go-to, and where I always, always bring visiting friends. Seriously, since moving to the area a little over a year ago, I've probably consumed 100 Caprese sandwiches from this place (shameless, I know.) Their beer selection is out of this world, not just in volume but it quality (I stick with a couple favorites but my boyfriend orders something new every time) and their burgers/sandwiches are the perfect combo of pub-chic + gourmet. ALSO, the service is really fantastic. The bar staff spend the right amount of time with you and are super helpful in their beer recommendations.

I'm not a local to Madison, but in my two visits to the city I came to Brasserie V. The first time I came I was with some friends and we had a nice meat and cheese platter. I marveled at the massive beer menu and was really impressed by this place. Later on in that same trip I ordered the Duck Club which was great.  

The next time I came to Madison I wanted to return and try the duck club again. We came 10 minutes too late and apparently I could order it anymore cause the lunch menu was over. I tried to persuade the bartender, but he said he couldnt do it. Instead i ordered the Salmon BLT which was great.

Overall Brasserie V has an amazing Belgian and German beer list and fantastic food. The prices are a bit steep and the service is kind of stand-offish and awkward, but that could just be my impression of Mid-Western folks... lost a star for not giving me the duck club
Madison bars tend to have good American beers. Brasserie V has excellent world beers, focusing primarily on European producers.

3.5 star. 

I would like to diverge from previous stellar reviews on Brasserie V. It is a good restaurant. Definitely the best place for moules, frites, and Belgian beers in Madison. No question it is doing well on these aspects. But there is much for Brasserie V to improve. 

I have lived in Brussels for a period of time, so I am particularly thrilled that Brasserie V offers me an opportunity to reminisce my good old times. The beer selection is really comprehensive. You can even get lambic beer here! Really a gem if you are a beer fan. 

The entrees were less impressive. We had Moules et Frites, Black Cod, Duck Confit, and Angel Hair pasta. 

As many have mentioned, moules and frites are good. But maybe I am biased by my previous food experience, I thought the moules are good, but I expect more from a restaurant. This might due the inland geography of Wisconsin, making it difficult to source the best quality mussels. I have had much better mussels elsewhere. Fries are good. But after being to a pig in a fur coat, I hesitate to call this the best fries in Madison. That said, I still Moules+frites is the best entree we ordered. 

Duck and cod are standard, but the portion is on the small side. I am not sure about the idea of having pasta in a broth, thus not a fan of the angel hair I ordered

I have experienced inconsistent service. Had a great conversation with a bartender in my first visit last year, but in second visit, i did not sense hospitality from the waitstaff.

With $30+ per person bill, I think Brasserie V is slightly overpriced. 

I still like the place, and hope for better experience in my next visit. Hopefully by then I would update my review to a 4 or 5 star.

I was here last night and little out of my comfort zone. I think I'm about to get more comfortable with Monroe street if the rest of is as good as Brasserie V. I had a safe bet with a beer im familiar with St. Bernardus ABT 12, however I'm positive I couldn't have found something I didn't like or at least find interesting on their expansive beer list. Many different beers and countries of origin. I was impressed.

As for the food, like I said I was out of my element so I ordered another safe bet. I had the Fall V Burger. It was amazing, very fresh and I loved that it was on a ciabatta roll. I was also pretty pumped to see Nueske's bacon on the menu. I also saved the aioli from our frites starter and more or less spread that on everything else I could, it was great.

In all this is a great place, I'm going to be back with my beer snob friends who will die when they see the drink menu. The food made even a sheltered eater very comfortable. The inside is very nice too with a great wrap around bar.

We were pleasantly surprised by Brasserie V!  The food we ordered wasn't anything out of the ordinary (Smoked Turkey and V Burger) but both were absolutely fantastic. Everything was well-seasoned, and the portions were right on the mark. The beer selection was great, and the bartender that served us was really helpful and nice. 

Can't wait to go back!

This is a great place to go to feel a little fancy but relaxed in a laid-back atmosphere. I've had many enjoyable bites here, and, of course, they have killer mussels. I was disappointed at my last visit, though, when I saw the scallop entree. Don't get me wrong, three large scallops is pretty generous, but...well...that was pretty much the only thing on the plate. The greens and puree were very small. Think of a frisbee with a drink-coaster sized meal on it. Maybe it was visually unappealing, but I definitely could have gone for a small bite after, too. I still love their food, and will be back (especially if their chickpea app comes back!) but would have appreciated a little more balance in the portion compared to other plates.

I want to like this place. I really do. It has a great beer & wine menu, its food menu always sounds so good, its frites really are delicious, but meh, it always disappoints. I went there for lunch today with a girlfriend who's moving out of town. It was her farewell-to-Madison lunch - a place she had been excited about going to ("I've never been there!") and man, what a disappointment.

First of all, service is a mess. Individual staff are very nice and friendly, but they all seem to have no idea what the others are doing. Confusion at the front of the house about whether we - and others - had been greeted yet, with the bartender apparently handling the hostess duties because she was too busy? It wasn't crowded at all but it took quite a while for our server to show up to take our drink order and then we waited 10 minutes for our drinks to actually arrive - and since we'd just ordered bottles of Crispin cider, you wouldn't think it would be that complicated. We were there for lunch - who can wait this long for drinks and food at lunch on a weekday, for pete's sake? 

Second, I have never had a grosser sandwich than their "grilled zucchini" sandwich. We both thought it was absolutely awful. The "beet goat cheese" was more like an unappetizing smear of pink all over the toast. The "roasted bell peppers" and "grilled zucchini" were slimy and oily. The whole thing tasted terrible and looked even worse. What a bummer. 

Third, any place that makes you sit with your dirty, finished plates in front of you for 20 minutes gets dinged big time in my book. We pushed our plates aside and then sat there, talking, with those messy plates in our way until I finally signaled to our server - who was chatting with another server at the bar - to ask if we could get our check. I shouldn't have to get your attention to get our check - especially not at lunch when you should anticipate that after an hour+, we probably need to get back to work. I shouldn't have to sit with dirty plates in front of me for 20 minutes. Aren't these basics at most restaurants?

I work fairly close to Monroe Street and am always looking for nearby places for lunch or after-work drinks/dinner. I wish this place were a better option.

I've been here many times for beer but last time I tried the food as well. We went for lunch. I had the smoked salmon blt. The sandwich was very good and the fries were excellent. The mixed greens side salad was unexciting but tasty. I'd definitely eat there again.
The selection of Trappist beer is enough. Sold! White truffle and parm frites. Friggin' awesome. Great service from friendly bartenders. What's not to like?

When I was a young El, I often confused "brassiere" with "brasserie", but there's nothing but the breast, ahem, best served at Brasserie V.  Is that a letter or a roman numeral? Never mind. 
The only thing that could get me to ignore the frites with my sandwich was the lentils (and my faux attempt at healthy choices). Holy shit, those were good lentils. Cool, delicious, and with just a note of moral superiority. Exactly how I like 'em.

But yeah, if lentils aren't available, fuck the salad, imma eat my increasing weight in frites.

I've gone to Brasserie V many times.  The service is always great, the food is excellent (they have one of the best burgers I've ever tasted the V2 burger).  It can get a little warm, especially if you're in the back, but overall it's amazing.  They have literally a BOOK of all of the beers they offer.  And if you know nothing about beer, they'll ask you what you normally drink, and they'll find a fun one for you.  It's very personalized service, excellent desserts, and I love it.

As for the other complaints about space.... they're expanding into the old Premiere Couture next door so they'll be getting bigger!!!  Yay!!!  More Brasserie V!!!!

And a requirement, you MUST get the frites.  $4 for a cone with two different aiolis that change every night.  Best fries in Madison (we went fry hopping -- as opposed to bar hopping-- and tested all the fries in madison, these won, hands down).

Brasserie V - what does the V stand for? My most recent vice.

My criteria for a good restaurant (in order of importance):
1. Beer
2. Food
3. Service

WARNING: This place is hopping, so be ready for a wait, but it's well worth it!

The beer selection is phenomenal.  Belgian beers are infinitely complex and notoriously delicious.  Add to that an entire book of beer choices and you have an impossible decision to make. Luckily, Brasserie V's staff is knowledgeable and friendly, ready to help you make such a critical decision.

The food is SOOOO GOOOOOOD. I have never had anything I didn't love here.  Moules, frites, burgers, chicken or tuna salad sandwiches at lunch - variety with quality. I'm actually on their wifi right now, writing this review, and eating tonight's special: a burger with egg, crimini and oyster mushrooms, and rosemary and truffle bernaise sauce on sourdough. Only $13! Oh shit. The guy next to me just got the duck breast with door county cherries and red wine sauce. I guess I have to come back tomorrow.

The service: this is why I'm a regular. I live nearby and the staff is so much fun that I'm content to hang out at the bar and chat them up for a few hours while they endow me with sample upon sample of whatever 4 new beers they have on tap this week.
Very good food. Glad they expanded the restaurant. The original version of their burger is much better than the second version. The patty is very flavorful.

O.m.g.  The burger I had here served on ciabatta bread was one of the best burgers I've ever had in any city.  The pommes frites are amazingly delicious too.  Top notch rotating beer selection.  I usually write longer reviews, but the only thing that really needs saying is GO HERE NOW!!!!
Great selection of beers from Belgium and craft beers from the United States and Wisconsin.

The perfect Thursday night out. Friendly local bar and restaurant. The frites are amazing and so is most of the menu. Spectacular and extensive beer list too. Double sided bar area opening into more seating. They have a record box for listening to old vinyl too. Good service and a fun staff! Great for small groups or a date night.

Excellent! My husband and I popped in last minute, and we were not disappointed! It was bustling but we were able to find a seat at the bar right away, and we ate there. We both had sandwiches, and they were absolutely fantastic!!! I expected it to be good, but the food was so much better than I expected!!! I had the zucchini sandwich with beet goat cheese, and it was phenomenal! Along with the ham and lentil soup! We would definitely return! Great staff too!!

My husband and I had an excellent experience tonight on what will be the first of many visits to Brasserie V. We arrived for dinner shortly after 6pm to a bustling, but not crowded, restaurant (a good sign to us). They don't take reservations, and the hostess told us it would be about 45 minutes for a table, so we put ourselves on a list to be seated at the first available spot--table or bar. Only about 15-20 minutes later, we were escorted to a great spot at the end of the bar, where we received wonderfully relaxed and attentive service, GREAT food, and my husband enjoyed, um, several selections from their wide range of non-standard beers (and a cucumber dry soda for the pregnant among us, ahem).

Service: Surprisingly calm wait staff overall. From our stellar people-watching perch at the end of the bar (right by the wait station), they seemed to work like busy bees when they were working, and then drop into a lower gear until something else required their attention. No busy-bodies, no curt tones, no snippiness. Awesome. I told the waitress I was unable to eat unpasteurized foods (so none of their homemade aiolis, unfortunately). She offered other sauce options without batting an eye and pointed out the unpasteurized cheeses on the board before we even had to ask.

Food: We were feeling snacky, so we went for the frites (of course!) with pistachio oil and parmesan, the cheese board (two from Carr Valley plus St. Andre triple creme - yum), and their to-die-for scallops. Seriously amazing! Perfectly prepared (finished with what I'm guessing was a torch, just for giggles) and served on top of whipped cauliflower, a frothy butter sauce, yummy warm cherry tomatoes, and crispy prosciutto. Our waitress's reaction to our approval indicated that, yup, they're always that perfect. :) Winning.

Beer: I can't say how the beers were from personal experience, but my husband looked to be enjoying himself. :) We marveled at their selection and that we had only seen about 10% of their line-up before. So fun to try new things!

My favorite place in Madison. It's a good departure from the standard Wisconsin fare of burgers and cheese curds. 

I have been here about three times and have tried the moules et frites, duck breast, and the whole fish (it's seasonal, I think). Moules are standard (i.e., good) and frites are thin-cut and great. The duck breast has a citrus flavor and comes in a delicious sauce. There is also a large beer selection. Service is friendly and prompt. Prices are very reasonable. Portions are relatively generous. 

Weekend nights are crowded, but never more than a half hour to forty-five minute wait for me. 

The ambience is good for both couples and small groups.
Wonderful service by Josh at the bar. He was so knowledgable and friendly. We love sour beer and they have an awesome selection. A huge selection of other things to try too! Can't wait to come back!

We really like this place  My wife and I had dinner here on Sunday night. I had the pheasant and she had the scallops. Both meals were excellent. The pheasant was moist and the skin was crispy. The sauce, vegetables and sweat potato that accompanied it were perfect. Sunday's are half price bottles of wine and we had a good Cote Du'Rhone. We split the chocolate yogurt desert which was also very good. Our waitress was very nice and polite and she spent some time with us explaining the menu and dishes. We will definitely go back here the next time we are in Madison.

Went as the lone guy with three attractive women to try and impress them, despite having brother status to two, and husband status to the third. It worked anyway.

They loved the atmosphere, decor and wine selection. I love the Belgian beers, and later went off course to try a banana mead and a watermelon ale. The bartender figured out my tastes quickly and plied me with samples. Totally my weakness. Everybody got what they wanted.

I've been here 4 times, and the food is great. People are friendly. Service was good. It's busy for a reason. If I lived closer, it would be dangerous.  My only downer is parking can be tough, and the prices are higher than I want for a neighborhood bar. They are trying to be a foodie destination instead.

Been there like three or four times, each time it's great.  I think I had the mussels with chorizo once and was like "so what" but every other time it's been a really good meal.  I really like their bolognese with the pepper farfalle.... it's really about as good as that could be.  The frites: above average, not perfect... but honestly that isn't a magnet to me anyway.  The beers: excellent.  They're heavy on the Belgian selection as they should be, but there's always a couple I haven't had before... come Grand Cru or this or that.  Sometimes it's pretty busy... I'd recommend eating early, there isn't a lot of tables there.  I dunno how people go 2 stars on this, seriously... I mean I think 3 is starting to get bad.... 2, really?  Maybe if you don't like beer... but that's like going to a pizza place knowing you hate pizza.  How many times you been there... try it again, goddamn.

Yum! Brasserie V is one of my favorite restaurants in Madison. I had it bookmarked for far too long and am so glad that I've visited.. multiple times.

The food here is amazing. Truffle frites. Get 'em. The regular frites are great, but the truffle frites are outstanding. They are a great appetizer to share and for a fair price ($7) given how plentiful they are. Divine.

My favorite meal here is the original V Burger. It's smothered in muenster cheese, onion straws, spinach, tomato and aioli, with some high quality beef. I'd tie this burger as best in Madison, next to Sardine's house burger. It's that good. I always order more frites with my meal (generally comes with chips, mixed greens, or the daily side) because I can't get enough of them for just a small up charge. By the looks of their menu, and thanks to mouth-watering pictures on yelp, they also have a burger that comes in different variations with the change of seasons.  

I'm not much of a drinker but it'd be a shame to dismiss how impressive Brasserie V's beer selection is. Like 250 beers impressive. They also have lots of wine.

Went to Brasserie V for lunch the other day, and while we had to wait awhile to be seated (they are a small place), the wait was well worth it.  I ordered the Ahi Tuna sandwich, and it was amazing.  The tuna was perfectly seared, the bread fresh and crispy, and the aioli was the perfect complement to the sandwich.  It was served with fresh mixed greens that were in perfect condition, and with a lovely dressing.  All this for only $10!  My colleagues were equally pleased with their choices.  I will come back again and again!
Take a ride over, you won't be disappointed. The Braised Beef Short Ribs are fantastic.  The new spring menu comes out in a couple of weeks.  We will return, with friends.

Full disclosure: we did not try the food on this visit.  
Last evening, a group of us were in the neighborhood and decided to stop by for an after-dinner drink.  This was a mistake.  This is not the type of place where you can stop in for a drink to round out the night.  You should be prepared to wait, even at the bar.  
My wife and the rest of our group sat at the window while I went to the bar to get drinks.  The place was moderately full but by no means slammed for the adequate amount of staff working.  I stood at the bar, with my debit card in my hand and the drink menu in front of me for what felt like nearly ten minutes.  There was no acknowledgement from anyone behind the bar.  It's like the staff was attempting to avoid eye contact as the stools to my left and right were both empty and I was obviously standing there, waiting for service.  
When a bartender finally came to my attention, there was no apology for the wait.  I ordered two beers, a glass of wine and a glass of water (for my pregnant wife).  The water came straight from the tap without ice or a straw.  Also, you'll need a PhD to navigate the beer menu, which could be a good thing if that is what you are looking for.  
I will not be returning, even if someone were to tell me it is the best food in Madison.

came here to enjoy a few drinks before the basketball game.  Was relieved that it wasn't packed and that we could get some good beer and an appetizer.  We order 3 different 4-oz pours of delicious tap beers.  It was fun to try something new and not get a full 8oz.  Also order the Frites.  Delicious!

Went to Brasserie V last night for dinner. 

The good:
-Service was nice.  Very friendly waitress who was adequately attentive.
-Ambiance was nice.
-Great beer list with some really nice imports on tap.
-The fries were great.  
-The duck confit was really nice.  Perfectly cooked with a crispy skin and the garlic polenta was amazing.  

The not so good:
-The House-Made Cavatelli was really a disappointment.  It looked and tasted like Hamburger Helper.  The pasta was fresh but overcooked and the sauce really didn't taste very good.
-The chorizo on the duck didn't make sense and was WAY too overpowering.
-The wine list when compared to the beer list is a bit lacking.  They could do something like wine on tap (using an argon system) to set themselves apart from other restaurants.


Overall I will go back and recommend it, but they really need to rework the Cavatelli. 

Yelp's price range of $$ is a bit misleading.  Dinner for two: 1 appetizer, 2 drinks, 2 entree's and no dessert came to $73 (includes 15% tip).

Good beer selection, cute/romantic ambiance with all the Christmas decorations up. Went there because my friend had said these were the best fries in Madison.

Went there for date night and tried the following:

Couple beers - I wasn't a fan of my first selection, and they switched my beer on the house.

Truffle frites - good texture, great aioli dips, but not much truffle flavor at all. 

Chicken pot pie - the flakiest crust I have ever tried with a creamy perfectly flavored filling. Would definitely recommend if you are craving some comfort food.

Fall V burger - a sweet (not savory) beef patty with honey, Brie, and pear. Just an average burger, not anything too special.

Good place for lunch. Service was quick and efficient, maybe a bit too much, I felt rushed in placing my order. Beer list was long, I had the German Kolsch beer with my summer salad. Beer was cheap, but the salad was rather pricey without any meat. My husband and son both liked their burgers. The frites was yummy.

I have been wanting to try this place for quite some time. I ordered a club sandwich and a lox sandwich for pick-up. Ordering over the phone was a breeze and my order was ready when they said it would be. 

Upon entering the restaurant I was already in love. Wish I would have stayed to dine-in. The bar area and seating was roomy and they had a lot of beers on tap. The restaurant was lightly dimmed and I saw they had dessert on the chalkboard menu, which I must come back and try. I'm all about my desserts. 

The sandwiches were both delicious. I ordered them both with a mixed green salad, which came with this mustard-ish honey dressing; not sure if they have other options, as I wasn't given any, but it was yummy. The sourdough bread on the sandwich was perfect and definitely my favorite part. I have a feeling you can't go wrong with anything off their menu. 

Great, friendly, and fast service.

This is a gem in Madison. The food is always delicious and the service quick and friendly.
A special shout-out to lunch here! They have a full menu but you can get a half sandwich and a cup of soup for $7. This is homemade gourmet "Belgian" food. 
I had the smoked turkey with bacon, avocado and red-onion on sourdough sandwich; there was a great spicy mayo in there too. Plus a cup of the spicy Crawfish soup. YUUUM. Happy girl on a cold winter day. Or was it the glass of Pinot Grigio that made me happy?
I have also tried the BLT and the smoked salmon sandwich too. All fantastic.

If you have not tried their V (vee) burger- you must. as well as the moules/mussels (flown in every day).

You may have noticed, I resisted the frites (just watching the winter waistline)-- but YOU should get them. They are PERFECT.

As other reviews note- it can get very busy at dinner time- so plan accordingly.

Had a business lunch at Brasserie V this winter on the recommendation of a foodie friend.  Comfortable atmosphere, good food, and reasonable prices.  It was one of the coldest days this winter (balmy high of 2 degrees that day) and it was a good place to get out of the cold and grab some lunch.  They were able to seat us at a table right away.  They seated us toward the back near the kitchen, which wasn't ideal but wasn't too noisy.  The service that time was prompt and friendly.  I had a smoked salmon BLT and frites.  Unfortunately we didn't indulge in any of the drinks, which is what this place is known for.  The person I took to lunch liked the atmosphere and seemed pleased with the food (smoked turkey sandwich).  

A few weeks ago, went back with some family and was actually pretty disappointed.  It was a Sunday night and wait was 45 minutes.  When we finally did get seated, we ordered milk for the 2 year-old, only to be told that the restaurant does not carry milk, only cream.  Seriously?  The food took FOREVER to come out.  The child's bedtime is between 8 and 8:30.  We arrived there at 6:15 thinking that would be plenty of time.  We didn't leave until after 8:30 because of the slowness of the service.  

The parking is difficult, similar to all the businesses along Monroe St.  Won't be going back.  Ever.

Um, first of all, let me say this--$21.00 for unlimited mussels and frites. Are you kidding me?!

We tried all three broths--the awesome classic, the St. Bernardus wit, and the final one made with Jordanal farms sausage. All three were delicious, and excellent.

The frites were fresh, crispy, and delightful. NEVERENDING EVERYTHING.

I'm stuffed. Near the end, we noticed that a lot more of the mussels were closed, rather than open--it's a sign that they were probably cooking them too quickly. That's where the star comes off.

Everything was great, though. I have less than a week left in Madtown, and I'm thrilled Brasserie V was one of the stops.

4.5 stars. As other patrons have written, they have the best fries and the best beer selection in town. This alone is enough to make Brasserie V a destination. 

Make no mistake though, this is a small bar and it's often crowded. When you add slow service, a visit during a prime eating hour can seem excruciatingly long.

Their burgers are more of an old-fashioned 'chopped steak' on a bun. Very un-burger-like, in that they're lean and meaty instead of greasy. But they're great. Fries come with two rotating aiolis and are delicious home cut double-fried delicacies, crispy on the outside, soft and pillowy on the inside. The mussels with fries is worth ordering, though I don't think their take on shellfish is anything spectacular. 

They have a superb selection of Belgian beer here, one to rival big-city gastropubs.

Amazing beer selection, excellent food. 
A little on the pricy side, but you get what you pay for. 
Great moules frites, wonderful sour selection. Its the sort of place you can order anything off the menu and its going to be great. 
Service and decor are A+

Went with a friend on a weeknight, early, a tad before 6 p.m., so there wasn't too big of an issue for parking. Streets/sidewalk still filled with snow, but hey, it is Wisconsin.

I would have liked to have tried a beer, but I wasn't in the mood, however the list is extensive an a beer snob would be very happy.

My friend and I ordered the moules frites to share with plans to order more food. While it tasted fine, towards the end of my meal and for the rest of my night I felt like I had been punched in the gut. 

We walked out and I said one thing to my friend, "if that waitress had a wee bit of humor or an outgoing attitude, she could make a killing in that place on tips". And had we had that kind of service I would have left a $20 tip for a $32 bill. Instead, I left a comfortable $6. Seriously, can't anyone train these yutes to service people, upsell, and ultimately make a killing on tips. 

I'm so tired of that. Come on people-

Brasserie V is a staple in the Monroe street area. It's been around for a while (at least 8 years? Don't quote me on that) and there are a few great constants.

1) Their beer selection.
Wowza, this makes me want to come here in and of itself. They have a good size tap list with beers I've never even heard of from places like Spain and Denmark and much more. You can order 4.5 oz glasses as well as a full pint of the on tap stuff so you can try more than one easily. Haven't been disappointed yet with any beers I've tried! They also have an extensive selection of bottled beers if none of the taps strike your fancy.

2) Their food.
Now, I'd come here for point 1 alone, but what makes this place even better is the food! It's not standard "bar food," it's better. Their moules and frites are my favorite choice always (mussels and fries for the uninitiated). Their tender, PEI mussels always taste fresh and perfect, with some nice frites and aioli to top it off. I would say I've tried other entrees... But I don't think I have. It's that good. I had a great tomato basil soup last night though! And my friends like the burger.

3) The ambiance.
Lots of wood, and a nice warm vibe. Service is good, and the bartenders are very knowledgeable. I'd take a date here!

It can be hard to park depending on the day and time, and sometimes the meals can be a little pricey, but overall a great place to have dinner with friends!

We were outrunning a derecho in my 2004 Saturn Ion, coming from Iowa County in the west.  Madison, home to a phenomenal restaurant scene, was where we stopped for lunch.

Brasserie V was open a little later in the afternoon on a Monday in June.  It had a super deep beer list, featuring not only Wisconsin's finest, but also many rare Belgian beers.  The frites were calling.

The frites here are perfect vehicles (unlike Saturn Ions) for the herby mayo and aoili that accompany them.  I also had a rich pastrami reuben with acidic apple salad.  Then we had to get back in the car to race the storm.

Brasserie V is one of Madison's great neighborhood restaurants.

HORRIBLY UNPROFESSIONAL. I made a reservation for my 22nd birthday and when I got there, they said they had no idea what I was talking about and that they don't take reservations. I had spoken with an employee there 4 hours beforehand and she assured me that the table would be prepared for our reservation at 7 pm. Not only were they unprepared, they were also extremely condescending, saying that there's no way someone took my reservation and insinuating that I must be lying to them. They made us wait OVER AN HOUR for a table on my birthday even though I'd made a reservation. 

When I spoke to the manager about this disaster, he was horribly insulting and patronizing, and his only token of reparation was ONE order of frites (the cheapest appetizer) for the 11 people in my party. Not only that, but the server forgot to put in one person's order, so while we all got our food, he had to wait 10+ minutes for his food. Unacceptable. 

This was the worst restaurant experience I've ever had and my friends and I will never return. They certainly do not care about customer satisfaction, considering a simple offer of a round of drinks and an apology was all it would've taken to make amends for the false information I had received.

Disappointing, service inattentive and food was not good. "Frites" that were offered were small broken end pieces of potato. Dipping sauce that came with calamari looked like it was "used" cup from a previous customer - food pieces and dipping marks in the sauce container that was presented to us as new out of the kitchen (yuck)

This is my favorite place to go for beer--the only place I can get a La Chouffe Beer in Madison.  Have the frites!  The soups change frequently and are excellent.  I have had almost every entrée on the menu and I have not been disappointed yet.  

Only drawback is that it gets a little noisy-and they do not take reservations, so on a Thursday through Saturday, you need to get there early, or take a seat at the bar.
Similar atmosphere to Jac's down the street, but the food is much better. Also, excellent selection of fancy beers. Very small restaurant! Love the atmosphere!
We're regulars here. Love the fresh European style food and endless list of tasty beers. I really appreciate the healthy kids menu. Highly recomend!

Went here with a friend.  The atmosphere is friendly.  It is small and crowded but we ended up sitting at the bar.  I ordered the Croque Monsieur and let me tell you...IT WAS REALLY TASTY!   The fries were really good as they were seasoned just right.  Our bar tender was really nice and attentive.  I willl return when I come back to Madison!!!

My new favorite place in Madison!  They upgraded that Belgian salad and I loved it!  Got a yummy piece of bacon in every bite.  Dressing was perfect.  Soup was fabulous, mussels and frites outstanding.  Server was attentive.  Will be back!!!

We popped in here for a few drinks after dinner.  So I have yet to eat here.  However, I can not wait!

The service was impeccable.  The bartenders were fun, knowledgeable and fun to converse with.  

The beer list was amazing!  PAGES upon PAGES!  Decent prices for the beers as well.  A half liter for a German doppelbock was $6!  Wow!  

I had an Augustiner Helles which is nearly impossible to find in the states.  They have the glasses that match the beer and just overall delicious options.  Ciders?  Try the six pear ciders they have in bottles.

We were there on 4-20 in the afternoon and 2 of us had the Seafood Rice soup. WTF???? How is is possible to make a soup so bland??? Did you break into a hospital & steal their soup recipes???? I haven't recently had surgery, I can handle spices... I swear!!!!  It wasn't just me, my cousin felt the same way. It was like cloudy water with 1 tiny shrimp and occasional carrots.

I also had the half a sandwich of turkey which I think when I said hold the dressing also meant hold the turkey. It had all the fixings and 1 tiny piece of lonely turkey. I was sad to eat it because it looked so tiny and fragile. 

My husband ordered the full sized turkey sandwich and wasn't quite sure what he got but he found it delicious enough not to say anything about it till after the meal.

We had the mussels and they were excellent with a superb taste (clearly not made by the person making hospital soup). Our server was also excellent, friendly, funny and on top of everything, so it was a bit confusing.

This is another "can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet" place. Brasserie V has been one of our favorites since they opened. Foremost for me is the beer selection, which is one of the best I know anywhere, and I'm a bit of a beer hunter. Belgians are their forté, but they source great brews from all over the world. The staff knows their stuff, too. I never hesitate to follow their recommendations. You don't even need a taste, just go with it. 

The food is just as good as the beer, with a traditional brasserie menu that's very well executed. The V burger, steak frites, and moules et frites are favorites.

Was not that impressed. Had a bowl of the flavorless squash soup followed up by a chicken entree. The chicken entree was floating in an unappetizing amount of water. Taste was unremarkable for this entree also. There are far better restaurants on Monroe Street.

There was just nothing not to love about Brasserie V.  

We had a table of 6, with only 5 people arriving on time.  Our missing friend ended up being about 45-60 minutes late, and we did not order food until the latter half of that time frame.  Sure, we ordered beers, but we felt bad about absorbing a lot of table space on a busy Saturday night.  The waitstaff didn't even give us the stink eye.  They were pleasant (downright friendly, even) and professional.  

Allow me to rhapsodize about their beer selection.  I was overwhelmed and elated by it.  I'm pretty sure that I have never seen such an extensive beer list.  They have something like 10-15 Belgian beers on tap (and, like, 50+ in bottles), complete with the appropriate fancy glasses to serve them in.  I am kind of a whore for drinks being served in the correct glass (which was my one beef with Tex Tubb's margaritas--a rocks glass?!  Come on!).  I would highly recommend the "Saxo" and "Poperings Hommel Ale."  That Poperings....man, oh man.  It was the most perfect beer I've ever tasted.  All of the beers that my dining companions had (both dark and light) were also phenomenal.  I'd also like to point out that, if you request it, you can get as many samples of the beers on tap as you'd like.  Seriously.

I tried Moule et Frites and in no way was I disappointed.  They bring you a medium-sized mixing bowl full of mussels, drowning in a garlic-butter sauce.  Cue drooling here.  They then plop down a huge metal cone full (FULL) of perfectly cut, spiced, and cooked frites.  Oh, sweet jesus.  While I was face down in my bowl of mussels, I heard things like, "This steak is $@*&$!% fantastic," and "Ohhhh, the beer braised kale."  Nobody was less than 100% enamored with their food.

On top of everything else, the place is charmingly decorated.  It's cozy and warm and beautiful.  I love it and need to go back right away.
Nice environment. Great food and not a bad price. I'd highly recommend the v burger and the frites appetizer. But the service could have been a little more prompt....

Let me start off by saying I LOVE this place. But a recent bad experience left a bitter taste in my mouth. Went on 8/17, and was told they had a limited menu based on "kitchen problems." OK, no big deal. As long as there is cheese and beer, I'm good. My date and I wanted to linger and order several courses and beers, but when we ordered, we were forced to order all of our food at once. While we stressed several times that we wanted everything to come separately so we could enjoy the food and beer at our own pace, all of our food came at once, and very shortly after we ordered. Uncool. A table full of cheese, frites, and burgers, getting cold before we could get to it all; not the leisurely dining experience we wanted at all. When we complained, we were told that the dishwasher was broken and they were trying to push food out as quickly as possible. What?? So basically you're telling me you're purposely trying to push customers out the door as quickly as possible? If I wanted fast food, I would've gone to McDonald's. To make matters worse, our waitress immediately took our beer menu away; guess I'm not having another drink? And even though we complained, nothing was done to make it right--nothing comped, no discount, and frankly, a very insincere apology. WTF? Brasserie V?! If "kitchen issues" kept you from providing the quality dining experience I've come to expect from your establishment, you should not have opened.

LOVE the amazing selection of quality beers and fabulous recommendations from an attentive and knowledgeable bar staff!! This lovely neighborhood hangout is so comfortable and inviting! The Truffle Frites are a great app to go along with sampling any of the pours. Parking can be tricky and a bit of a walk, but definitely worth it! I like sitting at the bar best for the overall feel, but there is great space for small groups or tucked in spots for quaint and cozy gatherings. This is just an overall happy place to be in!!

We were here for drinks and as such didn't sample the full menu this trip, but the Croque Monsieur was very much on point. Our friend ordered the Patat Frites which came with the correct sauces! The knooflok is tough to find stateside, but it was very authentic.

Their beer menu is legit and covers most of the major Trappist selections you'd expect. Additionally they had some of the smaller Dutch and Belgian "brouwerij" including one of my favourite Amsterdam-based Brouwerij 't ijwitt.

We will be back...often...It is the first place outside the Benelux that left us a taste of our other home.

I am sure a three star will surprise some, so let me start at the end by starting they lost a full star for service (or the lack there of) and the value (too much price for too little).

I decided to explore and hit the Brasserie V this evening. It was recommended by a couple I had meet at Ale Asylum and had good reviews on Yelp.

I was eating light, thus only ordered an appetizer, the Belgium meatballs; they are absolutely delicious...all 4 of them (value issue).  The beer I chose, a Scotch Ale on tap, was also delicious as well, all 10 oz for 11$ (value issue).  So food and beer was great, but that darn value issue.

The service was sub-par, as it felt like I was wearing my cloak of invisibility.  I sat at the bar and waited about 5 minutes to be acknowledged and it was not that busy.  After getting a menu, it was not too bad to place my order, but I really think she forgot about me as she poured several beers other beers before mine.  It was such a gap that the other bartender asked if I had been waited on. Then the worst service came after I had finished by food and my beer.  I did not see the bartender for 10 minutes and I finally flagged her down and just got the check.  

I may try again.  Good service would have partially overcome the value issue.

Friday night at 7 pm:  this place was packed with a 30-40 minute wait.  While some may frown over hearing about a wait, I actually am tickled by such things because this tends to foreshadow what is to come.

Within a minute, my wife and I found a pair of open seats at the bar.  The place glowed with lacquered wood, mirrors, and glass.  The bartenders were ultra friendly and provided us with plenty of attention.  The noise level was elevated there but not overwhelming given the full house.  We carried a normal conversation without having to repeat ourselves.

The food was outstanding.  We ordered the Belgian Meatballs, 3-cheese board, and the Apple Swiss sandwich with side salad.  My wife instantly fell in love with the sandwich.  She added some of the bleu cheese from the cheese board to her salad.

The mushroom sauce with the meatballs stole the show.  Not only was it creamy and earthy, but it had a mysterious sweetness to it that I learned was from baked black garlic.  I used the thin slices of crunchy baguette to sop up every last drop.

The cheese board we ordered contained nuts and honey, Granny Smith apple slices, thin-sliced baguette, crackers, Moody Blue, Hooks 10-year cheddar, and manchego.  The wine list was a wee short, but we found our individual wine selections paired well with the food we ordered.

My wife visited the lady's room, and she reported it was very clean.

In summary, we fell in love with this establishment, and we cannot wait for another opportunity to visit.

Came here for the first time finally after hearing about it so much. First thing I noticed when I walked in was how good it smelled. Always a good first sign. Staff was friendly. My server was fine. Of course there is a huge beer selection so that is a plus for many beer lovers. I got wine and was very pleased with my selection. I got the VIlla Barbi Rosso. I started with the creamy root vegetable soup. I love soup like this that is puréed. Very delicious not too creamy just perfect. For dinner I went with the steak frites. Frites are fantastic the garlic aioli tastes very lemony to me but still great. My steak was cooked just perfect I thought. Big portion. I would definitely come back to try more things.

We stopped in for late afternoon drinks, a plate of frites, and split the burger.  I was impressed from the moment we entered.  There was a chalkboard near the door which listed the names of the servers and bartenders for that shift.  That was a nice touch and I wondered why more places don't do something similar.  The bartender was friendly and attentive.  The beer was spot on and food was great.  Will definitely be back.

What did Monroe Street ever do without Brasserie V?  I'm astonished at how unbelievably busy this place was straight out of the cage.  The beer selection is its signature and quite good.  The food is typical bistro and also quite good.  But seriously kids, buy yourself a few more restaurants in Dudgeon-Monroe.  The west-siders are desperate to EAT OUT.

Note: I'm adding an extra star here because I hear the chef bailed and opened his own restaurant down the street.  Poor form, dude.

Brasserie V offers a warm, cozy atmosphere and a high quality, unique beer list, making it one of the best places in town to hide when the sharp cold of winter rolls in.

I had the opportunity to finally try this legendary Madison restaurant when my parents came to visit, and we needed a place with tap options to eat. Upon arrival we were greeted by the hostess and told we would have a 45 minute wait. Okay, that was fine. We assumed there would be a wait because Madisonians hold this restaurant in such high regard.

The waiting space near the bar was crowded and we had to ask for a menu and drink list to keep ourselves watered during the wait. Unfortunately, neither of these were offered to us when we were told to hang around and wait near the bar.

The beer list was absolutely fantastic. While the list is not the largest in town, it may be the best assembled list. The variety, quality, and uniqueness of the beer available from Belgium and around the world makes ordering a difficult choice. There were around 8 beers I really wanted to try on tap. The bottle selection (200+) is absolutely massive and worth exploring on a future visit. The beer list is the primary reason for the four star rating. I would return JUST for more great tap beer.

Per Yelp's recommendation we got an order of frites (Not the ones with truffle oil... "Do you know what we do with truffle oil? Throw it in the trash." -Jet Tila & Alton Brown). The fries were pretty average. While the sauces were interesting, I think the hype these fries had on Yelp left me disappointed. I had higher expectations from a restaurant sporting this kind of reputation.

For dinner, I had the Burger V with a side salad. The salad was a small pile of greens (where is the color?!) drenched in a very simple vinegar-lemon dressing. Again, I had much higher expectations from Brasserie on this item. There was no innovation. Disappointing.

The burger was very good but strange in some ways. The best part about the burger, by far, was the meat. The meat was very high quality from Scottish Highland Cattle, and I wish all my burgers used it! The burger came on sour dough sandwich bread and lacked any kind of interesting sauce. For having "the best burger in Madison," I am left confused.

The service was slow, chaotic, and slightly strange. The server layout seemed spastic. Each server was assigned an individual table, but they all had tables scattered about. No one helped carry dishes out and multiple trips were made to bring items to the table. The end result resembled a pin ball machine with multiple balls bouncing about. Servers should have designated areas and work in teams with buses to bring a cohesive dining service to the guests.

Brasserie V has status quo food and fails to innovate with its menu. A restaurant of this caliber and reputation needs to innovate more with its menu items to avoid becoming stagnant. On the other hand, the beer list at Brasserie V is world class and worth returning for time and time again. I am torn writing this review. There are so many small issues, but the beer list delivers a truly unique experience.

Most definitely one of my favorite restaurants in Madison. We came in around 7:30 on a Saturday night but I didn't mind waiting about 20 minutes for a table because of their awesome vinyl record booth. It's a cozy booth for two where you can choose from a selection of records and play them on the record player! It was super cool and fun. A great date night restaurant. 

Besides that, the food is amazing. We ordered the butternut squash soup, duck confit fritters, mussels du jour, and the pork chop. Everything was so amazing. The mussels are definitely worth trying there. It's a little pricey but the quality of the food is worth it. Overall I would go back for sure!

We stopped at Brasserie V last night after a late afternoon movie.   It had been a while since our last visit, probably over a year.    There was an hour and a half wait but we were able to find a place at the bar and eventually decided to eat there.
The service was poor.   The bartending staff did a poor job of watching the status of drinks so we waited for a while when our glasses were empty.   The spots we secured at the bar had been occupied before us by diners.   But the staff didn't remove old plates, glasses and utensils until we asked.   And even then we had to ask them to wipe off the area.
The food was up to par.   Moules and frites were good, salad with duck was good according to my wife.
Overall it wasn't bad but the poor service made it a somewhat disappointing visit

I have a girlie crush on this place.  It's the perfect spot for a quite night out. We have friends who like to go here with us and it's always fun b/c we share our plates and always have the best time.  We get the steak, 2 frites & mussels, sometimes a salad and app of choice.  The beer and wine selection is wonderful as well. And, I'm so happy that they have expanded and there is more room now!

I was traveling out of town and stopped in because of the other yelp reviews. I had the spring V burger and daily side. It honestly was a runner up for potentially one of the best burgers I have ever had. I can't wait to come here again when I am in town. The restaurant was cozy, clean, and my hostess Alex was super friendly and gave me the recommendation on what to order. I highly recommend coming to Brasserie V!

This place specializes in grilled sandwiches and fancy Belgian beer. It is always busy and for very good reasons: Fine (and sometimes rare) beers, excellent food, and fast, friendly service. My favorites: mussels and frites, any sandwich (seriously, any sandwich), their Belgian-style burgers (caution: they use aoli). Five stars, no question.
No complaints - and I loved the Shitake Mushroom sandwich!!  GREAT flavors!

Two key things to know before getting to far into a review: 
1) They are a walk-in restaurant (no reservations)
2) They serve beer and wine only (though it is a very very extensive list)

We came here for the first time on a Saturday around 5 pm. There was a 30 minute wait for a table but spots were open at the bar. So my party of four sat at the bar, which I believe I would have preferred anyways over a regular table. We realized they had extensive beer and wine list. I had the Crispin Blackberry Pear Cider that I found enjoyable. 
We ordered some truffle fries to share as an appetizer. The fries were delicious on there own but the aioli dips they came with were so incredibly delicious! Making the fries with the dip a combination out of this world 
For my entree I tried the smoked Turkey Sandwich (cheddar, avacado, spinach, tomato, onion, and chipotle-lime aioli). I chose pub chips for my side even though I'm not typically a fan chips. But these chips were delicious and I also like to dip them in the aioli sauce from the frites. My husband had the V Burger (Fountain Prairie Farm Dry Aged Beef, Beer Battered Onion Straws, Muenster, Spinach, Tomato, Classic Aioli) on Sourdough Bread with pub chips and enjoyed it saying it had good flavor. My mother had the house special of Moules et Frites (Mussels, Garlic, Shallots, Chardonnay Broth) with the same truffle fries we had ordered as an appetizer. The muddled were delicious and it came with so many. The dish was $17 but we could about 35 muscles total in a cute little pot. About 9 were not open so my mom told the waiter and they brought her out  more then 9 more new ones. Their mussels special is a tasty and really good deal! My dad had the Roasted Cornish Hen (Fall Vegetables, Potatoes, Lemon, Thyme), he enjoyed it but since he's not a big vegetable eater he said the dish wasn't very big but the yen was good.
I would say the food itself was a 5 out of 5. The reason I gave it a 4 out of 5 was due to the service. They were pretty busy so I definitely understand why they couldn't be as attentive, however we sat right at the bar and are drinks were empty and non of the bartenders or wait staff that came by us asked if we wanted another or any water. And it was hard to get there attention because they were so busy. 
But I would definitely come back and eat here, the experience and the food reminded me of my trip to Belgium and their food and restaurants there :)

***Okay...FIRST off, let me just say that this rating is based on the food and atmosphere alone, because I am NOT a beer girl. If I was, I'd probably dig it, because they have a very...VERY extensive selection.

We decided to have dinner here after I had a long hard day at work. I almost wish I had chosen another place just because it was soooo loud due to the lack of walls or sound buffers of any kind. This place is small, but they still pack in the people, and it was just a bit too much.

When we arrived, the hostess told us that they were having plumbing problems, and it would be about a half hour until we could order food. We decided to stick to the game plan and sat at a table. The waitress came to get our drink order and said "Well, it could be a half hour, or an hour...who knows. Hopefully they're fixing it." Now, when you're hungry, there is a big difference between a half hour and a hour or "who knows". She did say that they could make frites, however. We decided to order those as a starter, but before we could even do so, she said that everything was fixed and the kitchen was open. YAY.

We still went for the frites to split, because we know they're known for them. I'm not sure what I was expecting on the menu...but nothing looked amazing to me(except the Moules et Frites) so I decided to go low-cost and  went with the Avocado BLT, subbing the chipotle-lime aioli for the regular mayo that it usually has. The sides were succotash, chilled red pepper soup, or potato leek soup. I love leeks, so I chose the latter.

The sandwich was okay, but nothing amazing--but a BLT is pretty much just that, unless it totally sucks.. Same for the soup. It was almost too thick. The frites were decent, and I liked the beet aioli that came on the side. Again, it was just so-so in a town with so many dining establishments that so-so doesn't do much for me.

I don't know if I'd ever go out of my way to dine here, but it was decent.

Such a classic for Madison. The beer selection is truly amazing! They have a great selection of all types of beer especially Belgians, my favorite. 

For dinner you can't go wrong with the mussels or the burger. They have a number of other incredible options but the mussels or burger are by far my favorite. Always ask what the mussels de jour is and if it sounds good, get that. Otherwise, the classic mussel are incredibly good. They come with frites and some yummy aioli, or you can always substitute for a salad or soup to be a little healthier. 

To add on to the good food, the service is always top notch and friendly. Whether you want to just grab a beer or go for dinner, this place won't disappoint and probably the best choice on Monroe.

3.5 stars to be precise.

Decor and First Impression : You enter at the bar area so you'd be forgiven to misconstrue it's true size. Follow the service folks and you'd find a much larger dining area at the back. The rather dim lighting and non flashy wall motifs sway a more romantic tune to this joint (Which is always a good thing!)

Food : Glance through their menu and you'd realize there is more "finger" food here than "cutlery". We ordered ourselves a Chicken Pate starter to kick things off. The presentation was beautiful and portioning perfect. The pate itself was seasoned just right, not too bland not too salty. The baguette slices were the right carrier for it and the pairing of almost compote like cherry really made this dish worth ordering! Tarty cherries with the mildly salty pate is tingle dance for your taste buds! I'd recommend this for sure.

Onto the "mains", we ordered a Smoke Salmon BLT sandwich and their Fall V Burger. The smoked salmon was generous and surprisingly went well with the bacon. The spinach was a better substitute for the otherwise obligatory "lettuce" in a BLT. All in all, a very good sandwich that came with a side of well made fries!

The Fall V burger was a tad more rare rare than medium rare. Nonetheless, the beef was of a fine quality and quite succulent. The bacon aioli was a much needed boost as the patty itself didn't have a lot of seasoning on it. Finally the slaw of Brussels sprouts was a very very good idea and so much more earthy to balance that beef.

To close, the food is above average and I'm sure their Entrees will be something worth trying to in future (note to self!)

I can't believe that I haven't reviewed this stellar restaurant even though I have been here at least a half dozen times.  Now that we live in the neighborhood, I definitely see the visits increasingly.  Everything about BV is solid.  The restaurant embraces the brassiere concept-informal dining complete with great beer.  One of my favorites are the mussels and fries.  They always have two options-standard and du jour.  With either, you can't go wrong.  Served with some crusty bread for dipping, this is comfort food at it's finest.  The waitstaff and bartenders are warm and welcoming.  Giving the concept and BV's execution, it is no surprise on how popular the restaurant is no matter what day of week you stop by.

This was my fifth or sixth time here, and the food, drinks, and bar service were all great. The one glitch this time was our super-flaky server.
She was pretty inattentive and mumbled a lot. I also think she might have been avoiding us..? When she would take orders/refill drinks at other table, it seemed like she was deliberately avoiding making eye contact with us. I couldn't tell if it was that she was awkward, annoyed that we had ordered our drinks at the bar (less tip?), or just didn't like us (interracial, 1 dietary restriction, weren't ready to order as soon as we were seated).
The capper was dessert. After our plates were cleared, we ordered the raspberry pot de creme. And then we waited. And waited. Over twenty minutes later, I was about to get up to find her to cancel the order and just get the check instead when she turns up with the dessert. She kinda drops it on our table, mumbles a weak apology about the delay, and scurries off. All that was on the plate was a wee ramekin of chilled raspberry custard: no powdered sugar dusting, no sprig of mint, no tiny garnish of 3 or 4 berries, no drizzle of chocolate or fruit glace on the plate. Points for presentation are nil when you have a white plate with white ramekin with a nearly white dessert. I can live with that. The boy thought the dessert tasted absolutely great. But here's my question: if all she/the kitchen had to do was plop a ramekin on a freaking plate, WHY THE HECK DID IT TAKE 20 MINUTES??
I guess I'd go back because all my other experiences were pleasant, but I'd walk out of her section if I got seated there again.

We went here for dinner on Valentines Day. Was very unimpressed. Atmosphere was great and waiter was attentive. We started with a potato soup that was tasty and then it went downhill. The frites were highly recommended. We were told they we're crispy and delicious they were neither, soggy and blah. We both ordered the haddock which was good but the serving was tiny perhaps 3oz. It sat on an unusual radish assortment that again was blah and not much there. We also had a red velvet cake & ice cream for desert which was delicious. We each had a soda. The bill came to $97 with tip. Now that was hard to swallow! If it had not been for the desert we would have left hungry. We do not plan a return visit. Not sure what the other reviewers were raving about.

Authentic Belgian food and beer with an upscale, quieter atmosphere.

Walking in here, it does remind me of Belgium. All wooden interior with two lengthy bars and pub-style mirrors. There is an extensive bottled beer list and also a small but well-curated draft list that included some very hard to find, excellent beers. I went for the Saison Rustique by Brasserie Dunham. Though Canadian, this Belgian Saison was out of this world good. That is to give credit also to the restaurant for caring for their kegs and draft system. It was served in correct glassware as well. Our server was very knowledgeable about the menu and the beers offered. 

I ordered what was clearly labeled as their house specialty, moules frites. The fries were a tad too sallty, but very tasty. The mussels didn't have enough sauce in the bottom of pot and the sauce was much too watery. It needed to be better seasoned and much thicker in my opinion. My wife had the butternut squash soup and liked it.

Overall, we had a nice time. The atmosphere was a bit more quiet, upscale, and intimate than I was expecting. I think it would do well as a date night sort of place vs. a beer drinking and quick eats gastropub.

The atmosphere was a classy, subtle elegance and dark wood decor.   The Belgium beer selection was top notch and stems to match. We didn't eat there, but I will definitely return for a meal. The french fries looked like they'd fulfill my addiction. 

Cheers!

Wow! I did not expect the special creamy kale soup and Brasserie V Salad to taste as amazing as they did. My husband had the moules et frites which were equally delicious. Others at the table had the kale salad and a smoked turkey sandwich and all raved about them. Great beer and wine selection. Lots of locally sourced foods. My only complaint is the service was a bit slow at times. Overall, an excellent dining spot.

I don't know why Yelp has this place listed as being French.  This is classic Belgian food.  There is no question about that.

I went with the classic moules frittes.  And I was not at all disappointed.  The mussels were not overcooked and the the broth used to steam them was garlicky and rich.  The fries were hot and salty and came to the table in the classic funnel shaped server.  I started with something that was described by our server as clam stew, but it tasted more like Manhattan style calm chowder than stew.  It was good, but not spectacular.

My wife ordered an ample and beautiful frisee salad as her appetizer and the arctic char as her main dish.  The char came in two very large thick pieces and I am told it was spectacular.

We both tried different Belgian triples and the beer menu at this place was huge with lots of choice and this gave one the opportunity to compare similar types fro different purveyors.  The beers we ordered were delivered with glasses from the particular breweries they came from and they were terrific beers.  They were not cheap, but they certainly were good.

The meal came with nicer toasty sourdough bread which was a nice touch.

Unfortunately we had quite a long wait to be seated, and the place was packed when we arrived, while we ate and when we left.  In an area of town with lots of trendy places to eat, that this place was so packed and had so many diners waiting is an indication of how popular it is.

The next time I go back to Madison, I will go back here.

Our vusit was, by far, my worst dining experience in recent history. Both the service and food was terrible. We waited almost an hour for cold food. Although the dishes were comped, the whole experience was a complete waste of time, as we left hungry.

PROS:

- great beer selection, decent wine selection
- best fries, hands down
- cozy atmosphere
- enormous serving size of mussels

CONS:

- not being greeted at the door upon entering
- the 90 minute standing wait
- the very expensive wines and beers
- the grit in the prince edward island mussels (such a no no)

Overall...  great place to hit on a Friday night for drinks and fries at the bar.
Long overdue first time here. Awesome frites. Memorable sandwich.   My wife tried a burger and loved it. Impressive beer selection. We'll be back. Great for our kid too.

++The beer list is enormous
+I haven't had a bad meal here
+The fries are good but I've had better
-Not a whole lot of seating

Also the cooks take "medium rare" more seriously than at other joints so get your burger medium or it will be a bit bloody

A haiku says it all:

This place has good food
Come for truffle fries and beer
Makes you feel fancy

Loved it!
Went for lunch and shared a salad, steak frites and a burger. Flavors were great. Homemade aiolis were really good (heart attack anyone?). Great beer selection. Fast waitstaff. Cute decor. Great for a date night or meeting friends for brunch.

My favorite restaurant. The apple and Swiss sandwich is delicious. I have been trying to replicate it at home and have yet to perfect the aioli and pesto. The frites and salad are also a must! They have different aiolis that they serve with the frites. Huge beer selection as well.

It's been far too long since I've been to Brasserie V, so I'm hoping writing this review will inspire a return visit on my part. I joined a colleague for dinner, and since we were on the early side we had no trouble being seated immediately. Service was prompt and friendly, and our server was kind in helping us decide what to order since there were some hard choices to be made. 

I ended up choosing the smoked turkey sandwich. Maybe not the flashiest, but I love a great sandwich and this was perfectly executed. Madison Sourdough bread held Neuske's smoked turkey, avocado, tomato, spinach, and cheddar (I skipped the onions) with a lime-chipotle aioli that gave the sandwich a little pizzazz. 

I obviously chose to upgrade to frites for my side since it's one of their hallmark dishes, and it was a great choice. They were crispy, well seasoned, and came with aioli that made them perfectly dip-able. 

Looking forward to giving their burger a try and having another go at those tasty frites!

I can only speak to the quality of the beer selection and a couple appetizers. So let's start with the beer selection - it's amazing. The extensive beer menu is complete with nice little descriptions many of the beers.
